keyTakeAways: A majority of Americans (56%) now view Donald Trump as a potentially dangerous dictator, up from 52% in April, indicating a growing public concern about his use of power.
45% of Americans strongly agree that Trump is a dangerous dictator, and 43% strongly agree he is waging an assault on constitutional balances and the rule of law, showing deep public unease.
These concerns are not partisan; independents are deeply affected, with nearly half strongly agreeing on both issues.
The 'No Kings' protests are not seen as extremist or violent, but as a reflection of widespread public concern about unchecked executive power.
Historical comparisons show that previous leaders like Obama and Biden were also criticized for overreach, but public concern is significantly higher regarding Trump.
Public perception of presidential power has increased sharply, rising from 32% in 2024 (under Biden) to 54% (under Trump), suggesting a shift in democratic sentiment.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article analyzes public sentiment toward Donald Trump in the wake of widespread 'No Kings' protests, showing a growing majority of Americans—especially independents—view him as a potentially dangerous dictator abusing constitutional limits. A poll by the Public Religion Research Institute finds 56% of Americans now believe Trump exceeds his power, up from 52% in April, with strong support from those who believe he is attacking checks and balances. While Republicans have dismissed the protests as extremist or nonsensical, the data suggests a significant public concern about unchecked executive power. Historical comparisons to Obama and Biden show that public skepticism over power abuse is not new, but the current level of concern is more pronounced. The article concludes that the 'No Kings' movement reflects a real and growing democratic anxiety, not mere partisan rhetoric.
title: Republicans are ridiculing ‘No Kings.’ A striking new poll shows Americans aren’t laughing
